title: Understanding my results
content:
### **What are scans and what do they show?**
You’ll have a scan before starting maintenance therapy and then frequently, e.g. for the first year of maintenance treatment every 8 weeks. 

Your care team will look at scan results for changes in the cancer over time. If there’s no change, this is a sign that treatment is working and should be continued if tolerable. If scans show the cancer has changed, your care team will discuss next steps with you.

### **What happens during a scan?**
These are 2 common types of scans:
* Computed tomography (CT or CAT scan), Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

You’ll be asked to lie on a bed which moves into a machine, shaped like a long tube. Scans can take up to 90 minutes. You’ll need to stay still and may also need some dye, which will be injected into your arm intravenously, to help make the images clear. Your care team will be able to help if you’re worried about the injection or being in the machine. 

It's completely normal to feel anxious about having a scan. Try deep breathing, meditation or listening to music beforehand. Planning something you enjoy after the scan can also take your mind off it. During the scan, try closing your eyes, doing some breathing exercises, or counting down slowly from 100 to help stay relaxed. Your care team may also provide ear plugs or play music, as the machines can be loud. 

If you’re worried about what your results might be, remember that you can always talk to your care team, friends and family or attend a support group meeting.

title: What if I miss an infusion?
content:
If you are receiving maintenance therapy, it’s important to have all your infusions at the correct time. If you miss an infusion, then your treatment may not work as well. 

### **Making a treatment plan that works for you**

Your doctor can help you plan your infusion appointments around any special requests, such as a holiday or family event. Try to tell your doctor about these as soon as possible so that they can book infusion appointments that work best for you. If you miss or know you’ll miss an infusion, let your care team know so that a new appointment can be made. 

If you are thinking of pausing or stopping treatment for any reason, it’s important that you speak to your care team first.

### **Your doctor may advise you to skip an infusion**
It’s possible that your care team may advise you to miss one or more infusions. For example. if you get side-effects from the infusions, and they start to get worse, your care team may decide to pause your infusions. 

If your maintenance therapy infusions are paused because of side-effects, then you should be able to start your infusions again once your symptoms improve. Try not to think of these breaks as setbacks. Everyone responds to treatment differently and your care team is making sure your treatment is best for your overall health.

title: Getting help with side effects
content:
It’s common to have side effects on chemotherapy. The parts of your body most likely to be affected are the areas where cells grow and get replaced quickly, such as your hair follicles, the lining of your mouth, your digestive system and your bone marrow. 

There are lots of different chemotherapy drugs and they can cause different side effects. Not everyone experiences the same side-effects, and they may not appear for months or even years. Some people are only mildly affected while others experience severe symptoms, so understanding what could happen can help you to feel prepared. It’s also important to know when to get help from your care team. 

### **Common chemotherapy side effects can include:**
* Feeling or being sick
* Losing your hair
* A raised risk of infections
* Feeling tired and weak
* Losing your appetite
* Sore mouth or mouth ulcers
* Diarrhoea or constipation
* Skin and nail changes

The chemotherapy treatment you’re having might have some other side effects and your care team will explain those to you. 

### **When to get urgent medical help**

Serious infections can be a risk on chemotherapy. Your doctor or nurse will tell you what symptoms to look out for and how to check your temperature. They’ll give you a 24-hour contact number to call if:
* Your temperature goes over 37.5°C (99.5°F) or under 36°C (96.8°F) (it helps to have a thermometer at home to monitor this)
* You suddenly feel unwell (even with a normal temperature)
* You’re passing urine (pee) differently than normal for you – either much less or more than usual – or it’s painful or uncomfortable to pee
* You keep being sick
* Or you have infection symptoms, such as a sore throat, cough, or feeling shivery or breathless, even with a normal temperature
* Needing to pee a lot or discomfort when you pass urine
* You have diarrhoea

Even if you’re not sure whether your side effects are serious, it’s still best to contact your care team using the emergency number they give you.

### **Remember**

* It’s important to tell your care team about any side effects you’re experiencing as they will be able to help you with managing them.
* Reporting side effects does not mean you will have to stop treatment, by reporting you can help your care team find ways to support you to better manage them
* If you are feeling down about side effects you’re having, remember that most of these should go away when you stop treatment
* Track symptoms from side effects with an app like this one – research shows this can help you to manage them and may improve your quality of life on chemotherapy

title: Preparing for my infusion
content:
It can be helpful to plan ahead for each of your infusion appointments. Planning will help you feel prepared and as comfortable as possible during and after your treatment. 

* If you’re travelling by car, allow plenty of time to get to your appointment and to park
* You may want to plan for a lift in case you feel tired or not well enough after the infusion
* Write down any questions you’d like to ask your care team

Here are a few things that you could do during your appointment to make the time pass more quickly:
* Bring some headphones and music
* Read a book or magazine; or play cards
* Use a tablet or phone with games or TV/films that you can watch
* Bring a friend or family member to keep you company

It’s also useful to plan what you’ll need to bring to your infusion appointment. Here are some suggestions:
* A drink so you stay hydrated before, during and after treatment
* Snacks to keep your energy levels up. Check with your care team if you can bring food
* Sweets or mints as this can help if your mouth gets dry or you start to feel sick
* Lip balm to prevent cracked lips
* Extra layers of clothes and a blanket to keep warm 
* Travel size pillow to support your neck while sitting
* Your phone – using this app, you can make a note of how you’re feeling during your infusion using the tracker function. This can help you keep track of your symptoms and treatment over time

title: Who’s in my care team?
content:
Different medical specialists care for you when you’re having treatment for bladder cancer. You will meet some of these specialists, while others work behind the scenes. You might hear about an ‘MDT’ or multidisciplinary team. This team is a group of specialists with a range of expertise who discuss your treatment options to ensure your treatment plan is best for you. The exact members of your team will depend on your area and your treatment plan. But this should give you an idea of who’s likely to be involved.

### **MDT members you’ll meet**
* **Clinical nurse specialist (CNS):** Gives you the information you need and supports you before, during and after treatment
* **Oncologist:** Doctors who diagnose, assess, treat and manage patients with cancer
* **Urologist:** Diagnose and treat disorders of the kidneys, ureters, bladder, prostate and male reproductive organs

### **Other members of your MDT**
Some of the other specialists are involved in your care behind the scenes. You may hear about them but you probably won’t meet them. They may include:
* **Pathologist:** Checks samples of your cells and tissues under a microscope to diagnose cancer 
* **Radiologist:** Interprets your X-rays and scans

### **What your MDT does**
Your team of specialists will have regular meetings and will work together to come up with the best treatment programme for you. They’ll recommend treatment based on:
* the national guidelines for treating bladder cancer
* the latest evidence
* the stage and type of bladder cancer you have
* your overall health

### **Other specialists you may meet**
You may be referred to some other specialists who aren’t members of your core MDT. They can support with specific needs and may include:
* A dietitian if you need help with eating and drinking
* A physiotherapist, to support with general movement and any issues with going to the toilet
* A psychologist or counsellor for emotional support 
* A stoma care nurse to help you manage if you have an opening made in your tummy after surgery (a stoma), so a bag can collect pee (urine)
* A district or community nurse who may visit you at home to provide nursing care

### **Your opinion is important too**
Your thoughts and feelings are important when it comes to treatment decisions. Make sure you have all the information you need:
* If there are things you don’t understand, ask questions
* Take someone with you to appointments so they can listen, take notes and talk it through with you afterwards
* Ask for key points in writing
* Contact your specialist nurse for recommendations of websites, patient support groups and forums
* If you learn about something you think maybe relevant or useful, share it with your doctor

title: Bladder cancer: What to know
content:
### **How does bladder cancer occur?**
The human body is made up of trillions of cells, which grow and multiply to keep the body working as it should. If the cells are not quite right (abnormal), or are worn out or damaged, they die and new cells grow and replace them. But sometimes, those abnormal or damaged cells start to divide and reproduce uncontrollably, which can form a tumour. Bladder cancer occurs when a tumour develops in the tissue that lines the bladder and other parts of the urinary tract.

### **What is staging and grading of bladder cancer?**
**Cancer staging** describes the size of the tumour and whether it has spread from where it first started.
The cancer will be classified into various stages:
* Stage 1: The cancer has stayed inside the bladder (“primary site”). 
* Stage 2: The cancer has spread into the thick layer of muscle in the wall of the bladder. 
* Stage 3: The cancer has spread outside the bladder into surrounding tissues, and/or to nearby lymph nodes (“locally advanced”)
* Stage 4: The cancer has spread to at least one other organ, such as the liver or lungs, and/or to distant lymph nodes (“secondary” or “metastatic”). 

**Cancer grading** describes how abnormal the cancer cells look compared to normal cells and can help your care team know how the cancer might behave.
Bladder cancer cells are divided into 3 grades:
* Grade 1 – the cancer cells look very similar to normal bladder cells.  They tend to grow slowly and are less likely to spread outside the lining of the bladder. 
* Grade 2 – the cancer cells tend to be slightly faster growing and are likely to spread.
* Grade 3 – the cancer cells usually grow and spread more aggressively.

When discussing your results with your care team, don’t be afraid to ask if you have any concerns, uncertainties or questions. It’s very important that you understand all the information that you’re given.

title: How to manage changes
content:
After your diagnosis and throughout your treatment, you may find that you don’t feel like yourself. You may go through physical changes, which might impact your mood. Or your mood might be affected even if you don’t see physical changes. Everyone’s experience is different, but it helps if you’re aware of the changes that you might go through. If you have a better understanding of how these changes to your body and mood might affect you, you will be better prepared and able to manage those changes if they happen.

### **Talking it out**
Sharing how you’re feeling may seem difficult at first. Some people think they need to be strong to protect their loved ones, but it’s okay not to be okay. Talking to someone may help you to cope with these mood and physical changes when they happen throughout your treatment. 

Think about people you trust and could open up to. This might be friends, family, or neighbours. Or maybe you’d be more comfortable at a local support group with people in situations like yours. Whoever they are, talking to people may give you the comfort and strength when you need it, help you to feel less lonely and provide a strong support network for you to lean on. 

### **Talking to your care team**
If you have any questions or concerns about changes in how you’re feeling, please speak to your care team. They will be able to provide you with any support you need. 

It may help to write down what you’d like to discuss with your care team, so that you are more prepared when you meet with them. This can also help the care team to better understand what help you need, what is important to you, and provide the right support.

title: My mini glossary
content:
We’ve put together a list of some terms your doctor may use so you can quickly look up anything you don’t understand. We’ve also included a few terms you’ll come across in this app. 

**BCG treatment**
A type of treatment using a solution containing a weakened form of bacteria called Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG). This stimulates your immune system to fight the cancer (a process known as immunotherapy). 

**Biopsy**
A sample of tissue or fluid taken from your body to check for abnormalities. 

**Bladder cancer**
Cancer that forms in your bladder, the organ that stores urine (pee). Doctors diagnose the type you have based on which cells it starts in. 

**Cancer grading**
Describes how abnormal the cancer cells look compared to normal cells and can help your care team know how the cancer might behave. 

**Cancer staging**
Describes the size of the tumour and whether it has spread from where it first started. 

**Chemotherapy**
A systemic treatment (works throughout the body) with drugs that kill cancer cells. 

**Haemodialysis**
Filters out waste from the blood with a machine, used when a person’s kidneys have stopped working. 

**Immunotherapy**
Treatment for cancer that stimulates the body’s immune system to recognise and attack cancer cells. 

**Maintenance therapy**
Treatment that is given to maintain treatment outcome of an initial therapy and to reduce risk of worsening or coming back of the cancer. 

**Metastatic bladder cancer**
Cancer that started in the bladder and has spread to another part of the body. 

**Nephrectomy**
Surgical removal of a part or all of a kidney. 

**Nephroureterectomy**
Surgical removal of a kidney and the tube that connects it to the bladder. 

**Systemic therapy**
Treatment such as chemotherapy that travels through your bloodstream, reaching cancer cells throughout your body. 

### Terms used in this app

**Helper**
An informal caregiver such as a partner, sibling, friend, or loved one who has access to your app.

**HUMA**
The company that developed this app.

**User**
The person using this app.

title: How can I get a good night’s sleep?
content:
Getting enough sleep and being well-rested are a key part of looking after your sleep quality, especially while you are receiving treatment.

Sleep plays a key role in helping you to:
* increase your energy levels
* reduce stress and lift your mood
* strengthen your immune system
* enjoy your relationships

Building healthy sleeping habits is one step you can take to improve your sleep quality. You could try these simple techniques:

**Creating a bedtime routine:** Having a specific bedtime routine is really useful.  This will tell your body that it’s time to wind down, relax and start getting sleepy. Around 30-60 minutes before bed, why not try: dimming the lights, turning off your phone and/or the TV, taking a warm bath, reading a book or meditating for a while.

**Establishing a sleep/wake routine:** Try sticking to the same bedtime and wake-up time every day, even on the weekends.  Keeping to the same sleep routine will help to maintain your body’s internal clock, making it easier to fall asleep at night and have you wake up feeling refreshed in the morning. Avoiding naps will help too, as staying awake in the day means you’re more likely to fall asleep at night. If you’re so tired in the day that you really need to nap, try to keep it to only 30 minutes.

**Keeping a sleep diary:** Spending just 5 minutes each morning to keep a record of your night’s sleep, can be really useful in helping you to notice any patterns in your sleeping habits. When filling in your sleep diary, try answering these questions:

* What time did you go to bed last night?
* How long did it take you to fall asleep?
* How many times did you wake up in the night?
* What time did you wake up in the morning?
* How would you rate the quality of your sleep last night?

<sup>Job code: `UI-AVE-00283`

title: How can I stay active?
content:
Staying active is one of the most important things that we can do for our health. It helps to: 
* Improve how we feel
* Make us more alert 
* Strengthen our bones and muscles
* Improve our ability to do everyday activities

These benefits of staying active still apply when you’re living with bladder cancer and having treatment. Being active doesn’t mean high intensity exercising. Walking and gardening, for example, are great for moving your body.

You may not feel like moving around if you’re tired from your symptoms or treatment side-effects. But in fact, a little bit of activity can help with this. A good way to start is by trying to spend less time sitting or lying down each day. A little bit of activity is better than none. As you get more confident, you can slowly increase the amount of activity that you do. 

Think about how you can move more. Something like small, everyday jobs around your home will help build up the amount of time you’re moving.  Gentle stretches and exercises with resistance bands will help build your flexibility and strengthen your bones and muscles. You can even do these whilst sitting down if you’re too tired to stand, as you build up your strength.

Don’t try to do too much at once and talk to your care team if you’re planning activities that you’re not used to or haven’t done for a while, so they can help you build that into your daily routine.

title: What should I ask my care team?
content:
When you’re diagnosed with cancer and discussing treatment, there can be a lot to take in. It’s important you understand the information you’re given so that you can consent to your treatment, so ask your care team any questions you have – they’re there to help.

### **How to talk to your care team**
* Try not to feel worried about asking questions – your care team will want to make sure you understand everything 
* Make a list before you go to help you remember what you want to ask, and take notes during your appointment - it will help you remember things later
* Take someone with you – they can ask questions, listen, make notes and give support
* You can also ask your care team to write down any important information so you can refer to this after the appointment 
* Don’t feel embarrassed to ask about anything, from your sex life to low mood. Cancer can affect many parts of your life and your care team can support you with all sorts of things
* Repeat back what the doctor says to make sure you’re clear
* Don’t be afraid to ask for simpler explanations if they use complicated language
* Tell your doctors how to give you news about your cancer – for example, do you want the basic facts or more detailed information?
* Make sure you know how to contact your care team outside appointments

### **Useful conversation starters**
* Could you tell me more about…?
* Can you explain that again using different words please?
* There’s something I’m a bit worried/embarrassed about, could we talk about it?
* I’ve read something online – could we talk about it? 

## **What you could ask...**

### **Diagnosis**
* What does my future look like?
* What stage is my cancer? What does that stage mean?
* What can I expect to feel in the coming weeks or months?
* Who will be part of my care team?
* What will happen next?

### **Treatment**
* How could my treatment help? 
* What are the risks and benefits?
* Can you tell me about potential side effects?
* When will treatment start and how long will it last?
* What will treatment involve?
* How can I look after myself during treatment?
* What are the signs that mean I might need to contact the team out of hours?

title: How do I know if I’m hydrated?
content:
Dehydration (not having enough fluids in your body) can have negative effects on your health. Unfortunately, older adults are at a higher risk of getting dehydrated. One way to see if you’ve had enough water is to check the colour of your urine (pee). Dark and strong-smelling urine is a sign of dehydration. Other signs that could indicate you haven’t had enough fluids include feeling thirsty, tired, dizzy, or peeing less often than normal.  If you notice any of these signs, try to drink some water or other suitable fluids.

<sup>Job code: `UI-AVE-00275`
Date of preparation: `January 2024`<sup>

title: How can I stay hydrated?
content:
Drinking water is a simple and cheap way to keep your fluids up. Try to aim to drink enough water each day so that your urine (pee) is a pale, yellow colour. If your pee is this colour, then you’re doing a good job of staying hydrated and don’t need to drink more than you are. Your care team will let you know if you have any specific hydration needs, and you should follow their guidance over information provided in this app.

Consistently drinking water and fluids throughout the day, instead of waiting until you’re thirsty, can help you stay hydrated. Be aware that caffeinated drinks like tea, coffee, and certain fizzy drinks can dehydrate you and make you urinate more, so try to avoid them if you can. Sweeter drinks, like juice or concentrate, can help you get your fluids from sources other than water. If you do drink juices or concentrates, aim for no more than 1 or 2 a day, or mix them with water.

<sup>Job code: `UI-AVE-00275`
Date of preparation: `January 2024`<sup>

title: How can I remember to drink?
content:
Did you know that older adults may feel thirsty less often? As we age, our bodies can be less sensitive to thirst. Even if you don’t feel thirsty, you can find ways to remind yourself to stay hydrated. Try planning beforehand: set a goal for how much fluids you’d like to drink a day, and then plan when you will drink them. Have a glass of water, or a suitable alternative, with each meal to help you drink enough throughout the day. Setting reminders on your phone or on post-it notes may also help. If you’re on the go, try filling up a water bottle to carry around with you. 

<sup>Job code: `UI-AVE-00275`
Date of preparation: `January 2024`<sup>

title: Why do we need water?
content:
Did you know that sixty percent of our bodies are made up of water? Water plays numerous roles in the human body. Drinking enough water and fluids can support gut health by preventing constipation and bloating. It also plays an important role in get rid of bacteria from your bladder. Staying hydrated even keeps our joints healthy, helping us stay balanced and preventing falls. Your care team will let you know if you have any specific hydration needs, and you should follow their guidance over information provided in this app.

<sup>Job code: `UI-AVE-00275`
Date of preparation: `January 2024`<sup>

title: Can I make water taste better?
content:
Drinking plenty of water is the best way to stay hydrated, but sometimes it can be boring to drink plain water all day. If this sounds like you, try adding a slice of lemon, orange, cucumber or even a strawberry to your water to make it more interesting. You could change things up and have a glass of squash instead of plain water. Another option is to drink cow’s milk or a dairy-free alternative, as both are good for staying hydrated. Sweeter drinks like juice or concentrate can also add flavour, but try to drink no more than 1 or 2 a day or mix them with water.

<sup>Job code: `UI-AVE-00275`
Date of preparation: `January 2024`<sup>

title: What food should I eat?
content:
When you have cancer and you’re going through treatment, it’s important to eat a variety of different foods to get calories and nutrients. This can help you to:
* Keep up your energy levels 
* Maintain your weight and strength
* Tolerate the side effects of treatment
* Reduce your risk of infection
* Recover faster after treatment
* Feel better generally

There is no “right” diet when you’re living with cancer. However, a healthy balanced diet can help support you and can look something like this: 
* Plenty of fruit and vegetables
* Lots of starchy foods, especially wholegrain foods like brown rice, brown bread and oats – these should make up about a third of your diet
* Some lean protein, such as fish, chicken, beans and pulses
* A little dairy
* A small amount of oils and spreads, such as olive oil
* Very few sugary, fatty, processed foods

A balanced diet can help to support your body but eating well can sometimes be difficult. That’s because cancer and treatment can affect your appetite for many reasons. 

Even if your appetite is normal, treatment side effects may change the foods you want to have. For example, if you have a sore mouth, you may find cold foods and drinks, like ice-cream and smoothies, more appetising. The most important thing is that you are eating and keeping your energy levels up so if that means you eat a less balanced diet, that’s ok. Just try to eat healthy foods when you can.

You may hear about diets or supplements that can help fight cancer and ease treatment side effects, but many of these have no scientific backing. Some may even be harmful to your health. Be careful before adjusting your diet, and always check in with your care team to make sure any changes are right for you.

### **Get support to eat well**
Your care team can help with any questions about your diet. They may refer you to a specialist cancer dietitian to help you adjust your diet so that you get the nutrients you need and cope better with treatment.

<sup>Job code: `UI-AVE-00276`
Date of preparation: `January 2024`<sup>

title: Can I drink alcohol?
content:
For many people, alcohol is a way to socialise or unwind. If you enjoy a drink, you may be wondering whether you can have alcohol during your chemotherapy treatment. You may be able to drink a little, but it will depend on a few things: 

### **1.	The type of chemotherapy you’re having**
It’s fine to drink alcohol with most types of chemotherapy, but some interact with it which could make you unwell. Your doctor and nurses will tell you if you should avoid alcohol with your chemotherapy. 

### **2.	Side effects of treatment**
Avoid alcohol if you feel sick as it could make you feel worse. If you develop a sore mouth during chemotherapy, you may find alcohol stings. 

### **3.	Taste changes**
Chemotherapy can change the way food and drink tastes. If alcohol tastes unpleasant, you may not want it. However, your sense of taste should go back to normal after your treatment. 

### **Limit alcohol**
Drinking alcohol is harmful to anyone’s health. Even if you can drink alcohol with your treatment, it’s best to cut down as much as possible. 

### **How to cut down**
It may feel difficult to think about stopping or reducing your alcohol intake. Try these tips to help:
* Set a goal to limit alcohol – you can ask for your doctor’s help with this. 
* Track your progress in an app or diary.
* Don’t keep alcohol at home.
* Find non-alcoholic drinks that you enjoy instead.
* Ask friends or family members if they’d also like to cut down – reducing alcohol is good for everyone.
* Find social activities that don’t revolve around drinking, like walking in nature, going for coffee or watching a film.

If you think you might need more support, talk to your GP or call the national alcohol helpline: 0300 123 1110

<sup>Job code: `UI-AVE-00273`
Date of preparation: `February 2024`<sup>

title: What to do if I have no appetite
content:
During maintenance treatment, you may notice changes in your appetite. Feeling or being sick, constipation, and feeling less hungry are very common side-effects of maintenance. It’s important to take care of your nutrition and maintain a healthy body weight, but this may be more difficult if you experience these side effects. Your treatment may also make it harder for you to an enjoy meals. A few simple approaches to meal times can really help.

Here are some tips to help you maintain a healthy diet:

### **Plan your meals**
* Ask friends, family or a neighbour to help you shop and cook
* Write grocery lists in advance
* Stock up on plenty of nutrient-dense foods, such as meat (for protein), fruit and vegetables (for vitamins, minerals and fibre), as well as tinned foods like soup and rice pudding
* Include foods that are easy to prepare or require no cooking
* Cook larger amounts ahead of time and freeze meals into single portions

### **Be adventurous**
* If you aren’t tempted by your usual food, try something new
* Some days can be better than others – on good days, eat well and treat yourself to your favourite food
* Sometimes bland food can help when tastier food is not appealing

### **Eat little and often if you can’t stomach a lot**
* Small, frequent meals might be easier to manage than three big meals
* Or try dairy-based smoothies. If you don’t eat dairy, try nut butter for calories and protein. You can add protein powder to smoothies too.
* Try to include protein-rich foods in your diet, such as eggs, fish, meat, dairy, nuts and seeds
* Enjoy healthy snacks at times of the day when you typically have more appetite, such as apple with nut butter or carrot sticks and hummus
* Add more calories by cooking with butter, or olive or coconut oil, and grating cheese over meals

### **Relax and try to enjoy your meals**
* Without making food preparation a chore, try to make meals well-presented on the plate – food that looks nice is usually more enjoyable to eat 
* Make meals relaxing – chew and swallow slowly
* Take the time to relax in comfort after a meal
* Don’t be too hard on yourself – if you really don’t want to eat, do something else and try again later 
* Eating cold foods can help if you feel sick

### **Ask your care team for nutrition advice**
* Talk to your care team if you have questions about nutrition 
* You may hear about diets or supplements that can help fight cancer and ease treatment side effects, but there’s no scientific evidence for these. Some may even be harmful to your health. Be careful before adjusting your diet, and always check in with your care team to make sure any changes are right for you.

<sup>Job Code: `UI-AVE-00301`
Date of preparation: `February 2024`<sup>

title: Understanding my results
content:
Before your first chemotherapy dose, you’ll have tests to help your care team decide what kind of chemotherapy treatment will be best for you. You will also have tests throughout your treatment to check that your treatment is working, see if the cancer is changing over time, and monitor your general health.

The tests may include **blood tests** (see more on these below); **X-rays and scans**; and **physical examinations**, including measuring your height and weight.

Some chemotherapy treatments can affect your heart, lungs, liver or kidneys, so you may receive additional tests to check these parts of your body.

### Blood tests

There are three main types of blood cell: 
* Red blood cells – which carry oxygen from the lungs all around the body
* White blood cells – which are part of the immune system and fight infections
* Platelets – which ‘plug’ any injuries to blood vessels and make blood clots to prevent blood loss

Blood tests check your blood cell counts before and during chemotherapy treatment. If any of your blood cell counts are low, your care team may advise that you need to change your chemotherapy dose or have a blood transfusion.

The tests you have will be decided by your care team. They will be able to answer any questions you have about your test results and how they help to make decisions about your treatment. Below are some questions you might want to ask during your appointment:
* What kind of tests will I have? 
* How many tests do I need?
* Will I be told the results of all my tests?
* What do my test results mean?
* How do the results affect my treatment options?

If you are worried about what your results might be, remember that, whatever happens, your care team will be there to support you. Be open with your care team about what you’re feeling as they might be able to help ease your anxieties. You can also look into other types of support, such as speaking to friends and family, or attending support group meetings.

title: Reliever medications
content:
# How do reliever medications work?

Reliever medications are used to treat sudden worsening of shortness of breath or wheeze. They contain molecules that act on the muscles around your airways to help them relax, making it easier for you to breathe. They are 'short-acting', meaning they offer quick relief, acting within minutes, and their effect lasts only 4-6 hours. These medicines are often in a form of an inhaler but can also be nebulised or taken as a tablet. 

## Examples of reliever medications
The two types of relievers are short-acting beta-agonists (SABA) and short-acting anticholinergic (SAMA).

### SABAs

* Used for short-term relief of symptoms.
* Examples: Albuterol, Ventolin. 

If you are taking too much of the SABAs, you may experience trembling, nervousness, headaches or palpitations. 

### SAMAs

* Used for short-term relief of symtpoms.
* Example: Atrovent.

Potential side effects include a dry mouth, constipation, a cough, headache and feeling sick.

If you are experiencing side effects or if you have to use your relievers more than 3 times a week, it could be a sign your condition is not well controlled. Speak to your healthcare provider. 

### Learn more

title: Breaking the chain: How to quit smoking
content:
# Support and tools available
Quitting smoking is tough, but you're not alone. Many smokers recognize the health risks and have attempted to quit. 
Recognizing the challenge is half the battle and fortunately there is plenty of help available to help you make this important change.

Did you know that if you can make it to 28 days without smoking, you are 5 times more likely to succesfully drop the habit for good!

The American Lung Association offers a wealth of proven tools such as [Freedom from Smoking](https://lung.org/quit-smoking/join-freedom-from-smoking) to aid you in your journey towards ending tobacco addiction.

## Helpful tips for success
### Five secrets to quitting smoking:
1. **Focus on motivators**. 
You will have better and worse days, and that is normal. 
Are there any goals and motivators you can set for yourself to make it easier when it gets tough? Some people find it helpful to have a jar where they collect money they would have otherwise spent on ciggareters. Watching the money pot grow might help you stay on tract.

2. **Build confidence**. Feeling confident that you can stop smoking plays a big role in your success. Planning how you will stop and visualising your success can help you build confidence.

3. **Stress management**. Many people smoke when they feel stressed. Staying on top of your stress will decrease the times you might want to reach for a cigarette. Try mindful practices like breathing work or ask your non-smoking friends for tips on how they keep stress at bay.

4. **Recognize it's never too late to quit**. Wherever you are in your smoking journey, it is always better to stop smoking than not. It will make your lungs and wallet happier!

5. **Learn from past experiences**. Most ppeople who smoke have tried to quit in the past, and some were successful for weeks, month or years. Quitting smoking is hard, so don't beat yourself up if you tried before and it didn't work out. Think about what you have learned from your past experience, what worked for you and what didn't, and try again. 

### Seeking support
Share your goal with friends and family, you might find their support useful when things get tough. Professional help from organizations like the American Lung Association is also available, offering guidance and resources.

### Medication assistance
FDA-approved medications, such as nicotine patches, gum, lozenges, inhaler, nasal spray, varenicline (Chantix), and bupropion (Zyban), can be effective. Proper use, following directions, and combining with other quitting tools is crucial.

### Learn more
1. [How to quit](https://www.lung.org/quit-smoking/i-want-to-quit/how-to-quit-smoking)
2. [Top tips for quitting smoking](https://www.lung.org/quit-smoking/i-want-to-quit/top-tips-for-quitting-smoking)
3. [What to expect when quitting](https://www.lung.org/quit-smoking/i-want-to-quit/what-to-expect)
4. [Be prepared for challenges](https://www.lung.org/quit-smoking/i-want-to-quit/be-prepared-for-challenges)

title: Truths about smoking & vaping
content:
# The harmful effect of smoking
You have likely heard that smoking is bad for you, but do you know why?
Cigarette smoke is a toxic mixture of over 7,000 chemicals, with at least 69 identified as cancer-causing agents. 

Smoking is a leading cause of various health issues: Smoke can cause your lungs to become red, swollen, and produce more mucus. It triggers asthma attacks, and contributes to around 90 percent of lung cancer deaths and roughly 80 percent of deaths related to COPD. 

## Tobacco products
A tobacco product is anything containing, made of, or derived from tobacco or nicotine. This includes commercial cigarettes, e-cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, and various nicotine-containing items like pouches, gummies, or toothpicks. What you should remember:

* Secondhand smoke is comparable to direct smoking. It causes over 41,000 deaths every year.
* Marijuana smoke has harmful substances like tobacco, posing health risks.
* E-cigarettes have unclear health effects and raise health concerns.
* Smokeless tobacco is addictive and can cause cancer. It is not a safe alternative to cigarettes. 
* Cigars, similar to cigarettes, carry health risks, including cancer.
* Hookah smoke is similarly harmful to cigarette smoke.
* Nicotine in tobacco products is highly addictive.
* Menthol, a common flavoring, makes smoking more appealing and addictive.

## E-cigarettes and vapes
E-cigarettes, including e-pens, e-pipes, e-hookah, and e-cigars, collectively known as ENDS, are battery-powered devices. They let people breathe in a mist with nicotine or other substances. The main part is the e-liquid in cartridges or tanks. It usually has:
* Nicotine from tobacco
* Flavors
* Colors
In addition to these three componenets, e-cigarettes and vapes can also include many other chemicals that may cause permanent lung damage. It is best to not use these devices as alternatives to smoking. If you are thinking of quitting speak to your doctor about available support.

title: Decoding Spirometry, FEV1 & Peak Flow
content:
# What is spirometry?
Spirometry is a common breathing test that checks how well your lungs are working. It measures how much air you can breathe in and out. It also checks how easily and quickly you can blow the air out of your lungs.

It helps to diagnose lung issues like asthma and COPD and keeps track of your condition. This test can also check whether your medications or inhalers are doing their job. 

The spirometers you were provided with measure two things about your lung function:

* Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1): The amount of air you can push out of your lungs in 1 second. 
* Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF): How air flows out of your lungs in one quick blast.


## 1. Why measure FEV1?
FEV1 is used in diagnosis of lung conditions such as asthma and COPD.  Overtime, as COPD progresses the value of your FEV1 may change. Measuring and monitoring FEV1 regularly can help spot if your lung function is decreasing quickly. This will help your care team and doctor adjust your treatment for the best results.

* Perform FEV1 at least once a week.
* Record it in your Huma app.

## 2. Why measure your peak flow?
Peak flow helps you and your doctor to understand your COPD and to optimise your medications. For example, if you are having a COPD flare-up, your peak flow value may decrease, as less air is able to flow through your airways. Monitoring peak flow is important because:

* It acts like an early warning system, spotting airway narrowing.
* Keeping an eye on changes helps you act early to prevent serious COPD flare-ups.
* Perform peak flow at least once a week and report the results in the Huma app to stay on top of your COPD.

The video below explains how to use a peak flow meter. [](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6NBeSbiqeOo)


## 3. How to interpret results
Your personal best peak flow number is the highest value you have reached while feeling well. It is your baseline. You can use it as your reference when measuring your peak flow values.

To find your personal best peak flow number, take your peak flow each day for 2 to 3 weeks while feeling well. 

Your peak flow zones resemble a traffic light system:

* Green Zone - 80%-100% of personal best: All clear with no COPD symptoms. Continue daily medications. 
* Yellow Zone - 50-80% of personal best: Caution; consider quick-relief medication and potential adjustments in treatment. 
* Red Zone - below 50% of personal best: Signals a medical emergency, requiring prompt use of quick-relief medicine and immediate medical attention.

title: Managing daily activities with COPD
content:
# How to manage your energy
If you have COPD, daily activities such as dressing, bathing, and housekeeping can be challenging and may cause increased tiredness or shortness of breath. A useful strategy to help you with your daily activities is called **energy conservation**. It involves simplifying tasks to use less energy.

## The "5 P's" are key principles of energy conservation
### 1. Pace
* Maintain a slow and steady pace when walking, avoiding rushed activities.
* Take breaks or rest between tasks.
* Rest before feeling overtired, as recovery takes longer once fatigue sets in.

### 2. Plan
* Plan ahead and avoid doing too many tasks in one day.
* Space out activities like laundry, grocery shopping, and appointments.
* Spread out tasks over several days when possible.

### 3. Position
* Keep an upright position when sitting or standing.
* Avoid excessive bending or reaching, as it can induce shortness of breath.
* Change positions regularly to prevent prolonged fatigue.

### 4. Prioritize
* Focus on tasks that are most important or require most energy.
* Decide what activities can be done later or when energy levels permit.

### 5. Pursed lip breathing
Practice pursed lip breathing regularly until it becomes a natural part of your breathing pattern.

### Learn more

title: Quick relief medicines
content:
# How quick-relief medicines help
Quick-relief medicines, also called rescue medicines, help you breathe better when asthma symptoms start. They are usually taken as inhalers but can be given as nebulizers or orally. In hospital some are even through a special tube in their vein.

You breathe them in, and within minutes, they relax the muscles around your airways. This makes it easier to breathe. You can also use them before exercise to prevent asthma symptoms.

## Using quick-relief medicine too much
These medicines work well for about 4 to 6 hours, but remember, they are not meant to be used every day. If you find that you need to use them most days, you should tell your doctor; you may need a different type of medication.

If you use your quick-relief medicine too much:
* Your body may stop responding to it.
* You could become more sensitive to things that trigger your asthma, like pollution and chemicals.
* You might have a higher chance of getting a lung infection.

title: Asthma and poor air quality
content:
# What is the Air Quality Index?
The Air Quality Index (AQI) measures how clean or polluted the air is. It ranges from 0 to 500 and is calculated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency based on data about 5 main pollutants:

1. Ground-level ozone,
2. Particulate matter (PM2.5),
3. Carbon monoxide
4. Nitrogen dioxide
5. Sulfur dioxide

These numbers are put together to give us a score that tells us how safe it is to breathe the air each day.

## What counts as bad air quality?
You can check your most recent AQI on the Track page of your Huma app. Here’s how to understand whether it is safe for you to go outdoors:

* **An AQI under 50** means good air quality. It’s safe for outdoor activities.
* **As the AQI goes up**, the air becomes less safe to breathe.
* **An AQI above 300** is hazardous, meaning it's very unsafe.

## How to protect yourself from poor air quality
If your AQI is below 100, it’s usually safe, but pay attention to how you feel.

* On days with orange, red, purple, or maroon AQI:
* Limit your time outside to less than 30 minutes.
* Do less intense activities outdoors.
* Consider wearing an N95 or KN95 mask for better protection.
* Keep windows and doors closed.
* Use air conditioning to recirculate, or use a HEPA air cleaner.


### Learn more
1. [Poor air quality protection](https://www.lung.org/blog/poor-air-quality-protection)

title: Controller medicines
content:
# What are controller medicines?
Controller medications stop you from getting asthma symptoms or reduce their severity. If you are well, they help to keep you well. 
They are usually given as inhalers. Giving it through an inhaler means it can get to your airways more easily.

## Here's what you need to know

* Your controller medicine is the most important one for keeping your airways healthy.
* It needs to be taken daily as prescribed, even when you are feeling well.
* Your controller inhaler is usually brown.

## Benefits
Benefits of regular use of your controller: 

* Makes you less sensitive to triggers.
* You won't need your quick-relief medicine as often.
* Your daily activities become easier.
* Improves sleep quality.
* Supports exercise.

Observe these positive effects yourself over time.

## Side effects
Common side effects include:

* A sore throat
* Hoarse voice
* Mouth infection

These side effects can be reduced by having good inhaler technique, using a spacer if needed, and rinsing your mouth out with water.

title: Asthma control
content:
# What is asthma control
When your asthma is under control, you can lead a symptom-free life without coughing or wheezing.

Ask yourself these 4 questions:

1. **Daytime Symptoms:** Do you experience coughing, wheezing, chest tightness, or shortness of breath?
2. **Nighttime Symptoms:**  Do you wake up at night because of asthma symptoms?
3. **Quick Relief Usage:** How often do you need to use your quick-relief inhaler?
4. **Activity Level:** Are your everyday activities, like walking or doing chores, getting harder to do?

## How to keep track of your asthma symptoms
To see whether your asthma is controlled, complete the Asthma Control Test in your Huma App on the Track page:

* Answer five questions based on your asthma experience.
* Your score reflects your control level.

Your care team will see your score, which helps inform discussions about your asthma treatment.

title: Biologics for severe asthma
content:
# How biologics can help with severe asthma
Most people can control asthma with inhalers. However, some need extra help for severe asthma:

* **Biologic therapy** is a new treatment for severe asthma.
* It works by reducing lung inflammation caused by allergies or **high eosinophil levels**.
* **Eosinophils** are special white blood cells linked to inflammation.
* Doctors can check your eosinophil levels with a blood test.

## Types of biologics
There are different types of biologic medicines to treat severe asthma. Here are some of them:

### Xolair® (omalizumab)

* Helps poorly controlled asthma with year-round allergies (like dust mites or pet dander).
* You get one or two shots under your skin every 2 or 4 weeks.
* Common side effects: Muscle aches, joint aches, and fatigue.

### Nucala® (mepolizumab)

* Works for eosinophilic asthma.
* You receive a shot under your skin once every 4 weeks.
* Common side effects: Headaches and injection site reactions.

### Cinqair® (reslizumab)

* Works for eosinophilic asthma.
* Given through an IV infusion once every 4 weeks.
* Common side effects: Sore throat and muscle aches.

### Fasenra® (benralizumab)

* Works for eosinophilic asthma.
* You get a shot under your skin once every 4 weeks (at first, it's every 4 weeks for the first 3 doses, then every 8 weeks).
* Common side effects: Headaches and sore throat.

### Dupixent® (dupilumab)

* Works for eosinophilic asthma.
* Administered as a shot under the skin once every other week (after initial clinic doses).
* Common side effects: Sore throat and injection site reactions.

### Learn more

# Why regular asthma care matters
Regular asthma care is an important aspect of your treatment plan. Instead of waiting for problems to come up, taking care of your asthma on a regular basis helps you manage it better.

Good communication is key. **Here's what you can do**:

* Track symptoms and peak flow readings using Huma’s track page.

* How and when to take your medicines.
* What each medicine does and what to expect from it.
* Early problem signs and what to do when they appear.
* When to seek advice or head to the emergency room.

By being active in your asthma care and talking openly with your doctor, you'll get a better handle on managing your asthma.

title: What is asthma?
content:
# Asthma: What you need to know
Asthma is a long-lasting lung problem that causes inflammation and narrowing of the airways, making it hard to breathe.

## This narrowing happens in three ways:
1. The lining of the airways become inflamed and swollen.
2. There can be an overproduction of mucus, which blocks the airways.
3. Bands of muscles around the airways can tighten.

Watch the video below to understand how we breathe.

[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D0HvxftFDrU)

## How asthma affects your airways
People with asthma always have at least a little bit of inflammation in their airways at any time but certain things like dust and stress can make it worse.

### When the airways narrow:
* You might start coughing.
* You may feel like you can't catch your breath.
* Sometimes, you make a whistling sound when you breathe (that's called wheezing).
* Your chest can feel tight, like it's being squeezed.
During an asthma attack, your airway muscles tighten, and mucus makes things tougher. Asthma isn't curable, but you can take steps to limit inflammation and narrowing of the airways, like properly taking any medication that you have been prescribed and avoiding things that make your asthma worse.

### Learn more

title: Types of quick relief medicines
content:
# Quick relief medicines
Common quick relief medicines are listed below. Depending on your symptoms and severity, your doctor might prescribe you different types of quick relief medications.

## Short-acting beta-agonists 

Like albuterol or levalbuterol work within minutes to provide relief during an asthma attack.

## Anticholinergics  

They stop muscles from squeezing around the airways. Usually, it's used daily along with another medicine called an inhaled corticosteroid. Sometimes, it's added to your treatment to help with coughing, mucus, or wheezing.

## Corticosteroids

Like prednisone. These drugs treat severe asthma by reducing swelling. Often they are prescribed as tablets for a short time after people have had an asthma flare-up. Because these drugs have serious side effects, they shouldn't be taken long-term.

Remember:

* Quick-relief medicine can help with severe symptoms like coughing and wheezing.
* If your symptoms get worse or happen often, talk to your doctor.
* Be careful not to use them too much to avoid risks and side effects.

title: Early asthma warning signs
content:
# Identify early warning signs of an asthma episode
Early warning signs can tell if an asthma attack might happen soon. These signs, different for each person, help you start treatment before things get worse.
Monitoring symptoms in your Huma app under “Symptoms” helps you find patterns. Look out for these symptoms to see if you've noticed them before an asthma attack:

* Changes in breathing
* Making more mucus
* Runny nose
* Sneezing
* Itchy throat or eyes
* Feeling tired
* Mood changes
* Difficulty speaking
* Sweating
* Tight chest

For a more detailed list, see [here](https://community.aafa.org/blog/knowing-and-treating-your-early-warning-asthma-signs-can-reduce-the-need-for-emergency-room-visits)

# Signs of an emergency
Signs that you’re in a critical asthma situation (Red/Danger Zone on your asthma action plan):

* Asthma getting worse quickly
* Severe shortness of breath
* Skin around neck or ribs pulling in
* Struggling to walk or talk because of breathing trouble
* Breathing becoming fast and tough
* Coughing a lot
* Shoulders looking hunched over
* Medicine for quick relief not working
* Nostrils opening wide (might not happen often in adults)
* Colour change in lips, tongue, eyes, fingertips, or nails - could be greyish/white on darker skin or bluish on lighter skin.

Seek immediate medical help, as these could be signs of a serious asthma emergency.

title: Asthma friendly home
content:
# Checklist for an asthma-friendly home
Follow this checklist to create an asthma-friendly home by reducing the impact of some of the most common asthma triggers.

### Pollen:
* Keep windows shut, use air conditioning.
* Stay indoors on high pollen days.

### Animals:
* Exclude animals from the bedroom.
* Use washable rugs and slipcovers.
* Wash your hands and face after touching animals.

### Dust mites:
* Dust weekly with a damp cloth.
* Vacuum weekly with a HEP filter vacuum cleaner.
* Wash sheets weekly in very hot water (130 degrees Fahrenheit / 55 degrees celsius).
* Maintain humidity at 30-50%.

### Mold and mildew:
* Keep areas where mold grows clean (e.g. sinks, showers, bathtubs).
* Ventilate during showers.
* Use a dehumidifier, wear masks for outdoor tasks.

### Avoid fumes and smoke:
* Choose electric stoves, cooktops over gas.

### Air pollution days:
* On very cold days, cover your mouth with a scarf or mask.
* Stay indoors, close windows on bad pollution days.

### Strong scents:
* Avoid products with strong scents
* Buy products without volatile organic compounds (VOCs).



### Learn more

title: How to exercise with asthma
content:
# Benefits of exercising for asthma
Staying active is important for staying healthy, especially for your lungs. It's especially important if you have asthma. 

Remember that exercise can:

* **Improve lung capacity:** It helps you use oxygen better.
* **Boost blood flow:** It makes sure oxygen moves around your body well.
* **Strengthen muscles** and support overall well-being.

## Tips for healthy lungs
Follow these tips for healthier lungs:
* **Warm up:** Before diving into any exercise, warm up your body to prepare your muscles and lungs.
* **Take cold weather precautions:** When exercising in the cold, cover your nose and mouth with a scarf to protect your airways.
* **Check air quality:** Be mindful of air quality forecasts. Avoid intense activities when the air quality is bad.
* **Cool down:** After finishing your exercise, take time to cool down. This gradually lowers your heart rate and eases your breathing.

## What to do when you notice asthma symptoms
Here's what to do:

* **Listen to your body:** If you experience chest pain, tightness, or difficulty breathing, stop the activity immediately.
* **Quick-relief inhaler:** If needed, use your quick-relief inhaler as prescribed.
* **Relaxation techniques:** Practice belly breathing to regain control of your breath.



### Learn more

title: Asthma medication
content:
# The importance of asthma medication
Asthma causes 3 things to happen in your airways:
1. Make the insides of your airways swell up.
2. Create too much mucus that blocks your airways.
3. Tighten the muscles around your airways.

All these changes make it tough to breathe. But don't worry! There are special medicines that can help. Usually, these medications are given as an inhaler. They open up your airways, so you can breathe better.

Watch this video below to understand the different types of asthma treatments.
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iUv-_6Pog-4)

## The 4 types of asthma medication
Here's a breakdown of the four main types of asthma medicines:

### Controller medicines
* Reduce swelling and inflammation.
* Prevent symptoms.
* You need to take them every day, even when you feel well.

### Quick-relief medicines
* Give you fast relief when you have sudden symptoms.
* Take as needed and as soon as you notice symptoms.

### Combination medicines
* Offer both short-term relief and control.

### Biologics
* Only suitable for people with certain types of persistent asthma.
* Target specific cells or proteins to stop airway swelling.
* Given through shots or infusions for severe, persistent asthma cases.

Talk to your doctor to figure out which one is right for you.


### Learn more
1. [Asthma treatment](https://aafa.org/asthma/asthma-treatment/)
2. [Different types of asthma medication](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/asthma/treatment/medication)

title: What triggers asthma
content:
# What triggers asthma
People with asthma have inflammed airways that are sensitive to some things that might not bother other people. These things are known as asthma 'triggers'. Not all people with asthma have the same triggers. Some of the most common ones are: 

##### Allergies (Allergic Asthma)
* Dust mites, pollen, mold and animal dander

##### Irritants in the Air
* Tobacco smoke, air pollution, strong fumes, dust particles, and wood fires

##### Exercise 
* Physical activity, especially in cold air

##### Weather
* Dry wind, cold air and sudden temperature changes

##### Strong emotions
* Anger, fear, excitement, laughter, yelling, crying


Watch the video below to understand your asthma triggers.
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wBalpNH0h_g)

## Medicines that can trigger asthma
Some medicines can make your asthma symptoms act up. It's important to tell your doctor about all the medicines you're taking, especially if you plan to use:
* Aspirin
* Ibuprofen (Motrin® or Advil®) 
* Naproxen (Aleve® or Naprosyn®)
* Beta-blockers, which are usually for heart conditions or high blood pressure.

Also, be aware that ACE Inhibitors (such as lisinopril, fosinopril, and benazepril) might make you cough, which could be mistaken for asthma symptoms.

title: Measuring peak flow
content:
# Why measure your peak flow?
A peak flow meter is a handheld device that measures how well air moves out of your lungs. 
* It acts like an early warning system, spotting airway narrowing before asthma symptoms appear. 
* Monitoring changes helps prevent severe asthma episodes.
* It helps you and your doctor to understand if your asthma is well controlled, and to optimize your medications.

The video below explains how to use a peak flow meter.
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6NBeSbiqeOo)

## How to interpret results

Your personal best peak flow number signifies the highest value achieved when your asthma is under control. You can use it as your reference when measuring your peak flow values, whereby your personal best accounts for 100%.

Your peak flow zones resemble a traffic light system:

* Green Zone - 80%-100% of personal best: All clear with no asthma symptoms. Continue daily medications. 
* Yellow Zone - 50-80% of personal best: Caution; consider quick-relief medication and potential adjustments in treatment. 
* Red Zone - below 50% of personal best: Signals a medical emergency, necessitating immediate quick-relief medicine and medical attention. 

Remember: A decrease in peak flow of 20-30% of your personal best may mean the start of an asthma episode.

title: Symptoms of asthma
content:
# Common asthma symptoms
Not everyone's asthma symptoms are exactly the same but the most common symptoms include:

* Shortness of breath.
* Coughing.
* Chest tightness or pain.
* Wheezing (whistling sound while breathing).
* Waking up at night because of asthma.
* Drop in peak flow meter reading (if used).
* Knowing these signs helps you take care of your asthma better.

## Spotting early signs of an asthma attack
Asthma symptoms can appear quickly or take some time. But before the big signs show up, there are early warnings. These can be different for everyone, but some common ones are:

* Increased mucus production
* Runny or stuffed nose
* Neck/chin itchiness.
* Getting tired more easily
* Raised shoulders or slouching

Talk to your doctor to identify your early signs. Treat them as the "Yellow/Caution" zone, using quick-relief medicines when needed.

title: How to control your breathing
content:
# Thoughts and feeling matter
How you think about your breathing affects how you feel. Worrying can lead to anxiety, making you feel more breathless.

Be mindful of how you breathe. Rapid, shallow breaths make you tire quickly. Focus on slow, deep breaths to use your lungs efficiently.

Watch the video below to learn how you can control your breathing.
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wai-GIYGMeo)

## How to control your breathing
Breathing control is about gently breathing using your main muscle, the diaphragm, to help when you feel short of breath or anxious. Remember, it's all about using your body in a relaxed way to breathe better. 

Here’s what you can do:

* Find a comfortable, supported position.
* Place one hand on your chest and the other on your stomach.
* Breathe in slowly through your nose, feeling your stomach rise.
* Breathe out gently through your nose, allowing your stomach to fall.
* Make your breaths relaxed, smooth, and slow.

title: Food triggers
content:
# The link between food and asthma
Did you know that there's a connection between food and asthma? While food isn't a common trigger, it can affect your health:

## Sulfite sensitivity
* Some foods with preservatives called sulfites can make asthma symptoms worse.
* Examples: Dried fruits, packaged potatoes, wine, and more.

If you have both asthma and food allergies, they can make each other worse. Serious allergic reactions, known as anaphylaxis, can happen quickly and affect different parts of your body.

# Recognising the signs: allergy or asthma?
It's important to know if it's an allergy or asthma. Here's how to tell:

## Asthma indications
* Coughing, wheezing, or trouble breathing without other body symptoms
* If you have asthma symptoms before eating, it's likely related to asthma.

## Food allergy indications

* If symptoms come on fast after eating, it's probably a food allergy.
* Severe allergic reactions involve trouble breathing, hives, swelling, and more—follow your Anaphylaxis Action Plan.

title: Inhaler technique
content:
# Types of inhalers
Your controller inhaler comes in three types:

1. **Metered dose inhalers** (MDIs): These spray the medicine.
2. **Breath actuated inhalers** (BAIs): They release the medicine when you start to breathe in.
3. **Dry powder inhalers** (DPIs): These provide the medicine as a dry powder, not a spray.

# How to improve your inhaler technique
Watch the video below to understand how you can improve your inhaler technique.
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZUbYIQHbEgI)

## How to inhale your asthma medicine correctly

1. Before you take your inhaler, breathe out to empty your lungs.
2. Inhale the asthma medicine at a steady pace. Don't breathe in too fast or too slowly for your device.
3. If you're using a breath-activated inhaler, make sure you inhale with enough force to get the medicine out.
4. Breathe in through your mouth, not your nose.
5. Hold your breath for 10 seconds after taking the medicine (or as long as you can).
6. If you cough while using your inhaler, you might need to take another puff.
7. Wait for 1 minute between doses to let the medicine settle in your lungs. And if you're using a press-and-breathe inhaler, give it a shake between doses (but not all inhalers need shaking!).

title: Your personal best peak flow
content:
# Your personal best peak flow number
Your "personal best peak flow number" is the strongest blow of air you can do when you're feeling really good and your asthma is stable. It is measured over a 2-3 week period and tells you how well your lungs are working. This number is special to you and might not be the same as other people your age, size, and gender.

So, your plan for dealing with asthma should be built around what's best for you and how well your lungs can blow air when you're feeling your absolute best.

# How to find your personal best number
To find out your personal best peak flow number, do the following:

* Take peak flow readings at least two times every day for 2-3 weeks.
* Measure your peak flow when you wake up and also between noon and 2 p.m.
* Check it before and after you use your quick-relief medicine.

This rule helps you to understand how well your asthma is controlled. If you:

* use your quick-relief inhaler more than twice a week,
* wake up at night with symptoms more than twice a month or
* refill your quick-relief inhaler more than twice a year,

your asthma may not be well controlled. Consider planning a visit with your doctor and discussing your findings with them.

title: What is high blood pressure?
content:
# What is high blood pressure?
High blood pressure, or **hypertension**, occurs when the force of blood against the walls of your blood vessels is consistently too high. It is a leading global cause of death, accounting for 10.4 million deaths annually.

The primary harm caused by high blood pressure is an increased workload on the heart and blood vessels, making them less efficient. Over time, the force and friction damage artery tissues, leading to the formation of plaque and the onset of atherosclerosis, narrowing the arteries and creating a cycle that harms the heart and body. 

High blood pressure can result in conditions such as:

* Arrhythmia
* Heart attack
* Stroke

High blood pressure is often termed a **'silent killer'** because it may not exhibit noticeable symptoms. Regular monitoring, lifestyle changes, and early intervention are crucial for prevention and management.

## Few important facts about high blood pressure:
* Many individuals with high blood pressure are unaware of their condition due to a lack of noticeable signs and symptoms.
* High blood pressure typically develops slowly over time and can be influenced by various factors.
* High blood pressure cannot be cured, but it can be effectively managed. 
* Lifestyle modifications and, in some cases, medication are key components of management. Regular monitoring and appropriate interventions are crucial for maintaining optimal health.


[Learn](https://watchlearnlive.heart.org/index.php?moduleSelect=highbp) more about how high BP can damage your arteries.

[Learn](https://watchlearnlive.heart.org/index.php?moduleSelect=athero) more about atherosclerosis.

[Learn](https://watchlearnlive.heart.org/index.php?moduleSelect=hrtflr) more about how your hear can become enlarged and cause heart failure.

title: Maintenance medications
content:
# How do maintenance medicines work?

The aim of daily maintenance therapy is to help you breathe better throughout the day. Some of the medicines used in maintenance therapy work in a similar way to the reliever medicines by helping the muscles around your airways relax. These are termed "long-acting" as you can expect to feel their effect for approximately 12-24 hours. They are either long-acting beta-agonists (LABA) or long-acting anticholinergic (LAMA).

Other types of medicine used in maintenance therapy are corticosteroids. They work by decreasing the swelling around the airways, helping you breathe better in the long term. These medications are available as inhalers, nebulasers or tablets. 

Depending on your symptoms and treatment plan, you may be prescribed one, two or all three of these medications. When used together, they may have an even stronger effect.

## Medications used in maintenance therapy

### LABAs
LABAs relax airway smooth muscle by stimulating specific receptors. 

Examples: 
* Serevent Diskus
* Striverdi Respimat
* Brovana Neb
* Perforomist Neb

### LAMAs
LAMAs relax airway smooth muscle by blocking specific receptors.

Examples: 
* Incruse Ellipta
* Lonhala Magnair
* Tudorza Pressair 
* Yuperli Neb

### Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS)
Decrease inflammation of the airways, improving air flow. 

## Types of maintenance therapy 
### Monotherapy
Monotherapy involves using only one long-acting COPD medicine, and it can be either a LAMA or a LABA.

### Dual therapy
Dual therapy for COPD involves using two medicines that work together to open the airways in the lungs. There are two types of dual therapies, each with a different combination of medicines:

#### ICS and LABA combination treatments:
* Advair Diskus
* AirDuo RespiClick
* Breo Ellipta 
* Symbicort 3
* Wixela Inhub

#### LAMA and LABA combination treatments:
* Anoro Ellipta 
* Bevespi Aerosphere 
* Duaklir Pressair
* Stiolto Respimat

### Tripple therapy 
A 3-in-1 preparation where ICSs, LAMAs, and LABAs work together to help open up the airways.

Examples: 
* Trelegy Ellipta 
* Breztri Aerosphere

1. [COPD Medications](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/treating/copd-medications)

title: Exercise and COPD
content:
# Staying active
Doing moderate exercise for 20-30 minutes, 3-4 days a week, improves oxygen use, energy, mental well-being, sleep, self-esteem, heart health, muscle strength, and reduces shortness of breath.

## Types of recommended exercises for COPD
* **Pulmonary rehabilitation**: Educational and exercise classes in a group setting improves understanding of lung health and how to manage COPD symptoms.
* **Stretching**: Enhances relaxation and flexibility, serves as a warm-up and cool-down for other exercises.
* **Aerobic exercise**: Boosts heart and lung health. Activities like walking, biking, and swimming can be helpful. Aim for about 30 minutes a few times a week.
* **Resistance training**: Strengthens muscles, including those used for breathing. Try using weights or resistance bands. You can perform these exercises at home, and aim for 3-4 sessions weekly.

*Before starting, consult your healthcare provider to discuss suitable exercise goals.*


## Things to consider before exercising 

It is generally safe for people with COPD to exercise but you should not exercise if you:

* Have a fever or infection 
* Feel nauseated 
* Have chest pain 
* Are out of oxygen 
* Have increased shortness of breath 
* Experience worsening of other COPD-related symptoms 
* Feel dizzy, weak or unsteady

*Contact your provider right away if you are experiencing any of these symptoms.*

title: Mental health and COPD
content:
# Looking after your mental health 
Dealing with COPD might affect how you feel, bringing moments of sadness, fear, or worry. It's okay to feel these things, but if they stick around for weeks, it could be a sign of anxiety or depression. Don't hesitate to talk about it with your doctor and get the support you need.

## Recognising the symptoms of anxiety, panic, and depression
### Anxiety and panic
Anxiety is common in people who have COPD: 

* As COPD causes breathing to be more shallow, our brain can perceive this as a potential stressful situation. To keep us safe, our brain can trigger a stress response in the body, which we feel as anxiety.
* Panic attacks or sudden intense fear can change the normal breathing pattern, making breathing much quicker. This can worsen the sensation of shortness of breath. As you experience that, you might breath even quicker. This can create a loop where breathlessness triggers anxiety.

To avoid those uncomfortable feelings, you may stop doing things that cause you shortness of breath such as going for walk and staying active. This strategy can worsen your symptoms in the long run as keeping active strenghtens lungs and has been shown to improve mental health. If you are finding it difficulty to keep active, start with walking shorter distances or find a walking buddy to help distract your thoughts. 

### Depression
Clinical depression is prolonged deep sadness or emptiness, lasting more than a few weeks. It affects enjoyment of work, relaxation, and relationships, impacting overall life satisfaction. Untreated depression can limit the ability to stay active and enjoy life.

## Things you can do for anxiety and depression
### Communicate with your healthcare provider
* Discuss your mood and emotions with your healthcare provider.
* Work together to understand the causes and identify coping strategies.
* Consider consultation with a mental health professional for counseling or medication.

### Take care of yourself
* Stay active to help both your physical and mental health.
* Do activities you enjoy, see friends, and spend time outdoors.
* Manage stress and reduce shortness of breath through relaxation techniques and breathing exercises.
* Prioritize self-care, including a balanced diet, hydration, adequate sleep, and a consistent daily routine.
* Develop coping strategies and create a toolbox to handle stress. 

There isn't one strategy that works for everyone but trying several different ones will help you find ones that are right for you. Some coping skills to try include journaling, walking in nature, deep breathing, doing your favourite hobby. 

### Seek support
Don't hesitate to ask for help when feeling isolated or overwhelmed. Reach out to friends, family, neighbors, and your care team for assistance.

### Connect with others
* Join COPD support groups, such as [Better Breathers Club](https://www.lung.org/help-support/better-breathers-club).
* Share experiences with those who understand the challenges of living with COPD.
* Contact the [Lung Helpline](https://www.lung.org/help-support/lung-helpline-and-tobacco-quitline) for expert information and resource referrals.

*Remember, you are NOT alone.
Seek support from COPD communities and helplines.*

**If thoughts of self-harm arise, contact a doctor, the National Suicide Prevention Hotline (1-800-273-8255), or emergency services immediately.**

### Learn more
1. [COPD and emotional heatlh](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/living-with-copd/coping-with-emotions).

title: Supplementary treatments for COPD
content:
# What else can help with COPD?
Additional treatments, along with medication, can help manage COPD better, improving your daily life and overall health in the long run.

## Quit smoking
Essential for COPD management, because: 
* Smoking makes symptoms worse.
* Smokers have a higher chance of more severe episodes.
* Smoking makes medications less effective.

Thinking about quitting?
* Reach out to your friends and family for support. 
* Ask your healthcare provider about available support and medications that can help you quit for good.

## Join pulmonary rehabilitation
Pulmonary rehabilitation is a group-based program combining exercise, education, and support. It is ideal for those with frequent shortness of breath despite medication use. Some benefits of pulmonary rehabilitation include:

* Making your lungs work better.
* Reducing symptoms.
* Improving your overall quality of life.

## Try belly breathing
Belly breathing trains your diaphragm, a muscle that helps with breathing, to do most of the work. This breathing technique helps:
* People with asthma or COPD to manage shortness of breath.
* To control breathing pace, making each breath more effective.

## Supplemental oxygen
* Increases oxygen intake into the lungs.
* Doctors prescribe it based on test results like oximetry.
* Various devices are available for home and on-the-go use.

## Non-invasive ventilation
This is used for some patients with high carbon dioxide levels in their blood. It works by blowing air through a face mask. 
Non-invasive ventilation can lower the risk of death and help avoid hospital stays.


## Sleep apnea treatment
Sleep apnea can worsen COPD symptoms. The treatment involves a machine delivering air to keep your airways open during sleep.
It is important for improving sleep quality and overall health.

## Endobronchial valve (EBV) therapy
This therapy is a non-surgical method for advanced COPD and emphysema. What you should know:
* Removable one-way valves reduce lung hyperinflation.
* It only suits specific patients.

## Surgery
* Considered for advanced stages of COPD when medications and other treatments don't work anymore.
* People must meet certain health requirements and join pulmonary rehabilitation.

## Clinical trials for COPD
Clinical trials are research studies that test new treatments. Joining one lets you help advance the understanding of diseases. However, not everyone can join, so ask your doctor if you want to take part.

## Complementary treatment
It is used alongside standard COPD treatments. Examples include:
* Meditation
* Deep breathing
* Massage
* Dietary supplements

Talk to your healthcare provider to make sure a new treatment works well with your regular care. Be cautious of treatments making unproven claims.
