title: Planning for the future with COPD
content:
# Planning ahead
Facing a diagnosis of COPD brings challenging discussions about the future, including palliative and hospice care. Planning ahead becomes crucial to ensure you get the care that you need.

## 1. Getting the care you need
Palliative care focuses on enhancing comfort, treating your disease, and improving your overall quality of life.
Prescription medications and counseling address both physical and emotional symptoms, promoting your well-being.
Practical concerns, like care coordination and life-planning, are addressed to provide comprehensive support.

## 2. Understanding your options
Palliative care, available at any stage of your disease, is distinct from hospice care, which is provided at end-of-life.
Team up with your healthcare provider to handle both your physical and emotional needs, making sure the care you receive fits with what you want throughout your illness journey.

## 3. Getting paperwork in order
Talk about and document your wishes early, especially for times when talking might be hard. Involve your family or friends in filling out advance directives to guide decisions in the future. Prioritize these discussions to reduce stress for you and your support system.

## 4. Your living will
Your living will, or advance directive, details your end-of-life care preferences.
Decisions include where you want to receive end-of-life care (hospital, hospice facility, or home), comfort care preferences, the consideration of artificial food, when to stop treatment, and the option for resuscitation.

title: COPD action plan and management tools
content:
# Being in control of your COPD
A COPD action plan is a helpful tool that helps you take charge of your health. It lets you notice and deal with changes in your condition quickly, prevent flare-ups and improve your overall quality of life.

## Key components of a COPD action plan
### Daily Tracking
* Track COPD symptoms daily in your app.
* Monitor sleep patterns. 
* Observe differences in how you feel on good days versus bad days.

### Learn about the three zones
Based on your symptom severity, they can be categorized into three zones.

**Green Zone:**

* No COPD symptoms; feeling good.
* Continue with long-term control medications and prescribed oxygen, even if feeling well.

**Yellow Zone:**

* Increased COPD symptoms compared to usual.
* Symptoms may include worsened shortness of breath, increased tiredness, and coughing with changes in mucus.
* Follow your action plan's steps, which may involve using quick-relief medication or starting prescribed antibiotics.

**Red Zone:**

* Severe COPD symptoms or flare-up.
* Severe shortness of breath at rest, chest pain, coughing up blood, chills, blue/gray color in lips or fingertips, racing heart, confusion, or fever are signs to act on.
* Call 911 or seek immediate medical care.

## Management tools
### Deep breathing exercises
Chronic lung diseases like COPD can cause persistent breathlessness.
Practice deep-breathing exercises, such as "belly breathing" (diaphragmatic breathing), to help with shortness of breath.
Use “pursed lip breathing”  to relax airways and return to normal breathing patterns.

title: Treatment of COPD
content:
# Treatment goals of COPD 
While there's no cure for COPD, there are medications that can help you stay on top of your symptoms and live a fuller life. Available treatment options aim to:

* Control symptoms.
* Slow disease progression.
* Reduce flare-ups.
* Improve activity levels.

## Commonly used treatments 

The most commonly used treatment for COPD includes inhaled medications that help to open up your airways, so that the air can pass more easy and improve your symptoms. These medicines are called 'bronchodilators'.

### Relievers 
Some of the bronchodilators are 'short-acting', meaning they offer quick relief, acting within minutes, but their effect lasts only 4-6 hours. These are either short-acting beta-agonists (SABA) or short-acting anticholinergic (SAMA).

### Maintenance therapy
Other types of inhalers are 'long-acting', meaning it takes longer for them to start working, but the effect is felt for approximately 12-24 hours. These are either long-acting beta-agonists (LABA) or long-acting anticholinergic (LAMA).

Depending on your symptoms and how severe your COPD is, different inhalers might be tried. Some inhalers can have more than one medicine in them. This is called combination therapy. 

## Other COPD medications 

### Anti-inflammatory (Inhaled Corticosteroid - ICS):
Aim: Reduces inflammation, swelling, and mucus production in airways.
Often used in combination therapies.

### PDE4 inhibitors 
Example: Daliresp
Aim: Opens up the airways and reduces inflammation. Helps to prevent flare-ups.
For patients with severe COPD, it is taken as a tablet.

### Antibiotics:
Aim: Prescribed during flare-ups caused by bacterial or viral infections.
The full course should be finished to prevent resistance or recurrence.

### Vaccinations:
Aim: As your lungs are already under stress from COPD, vaccinations are important for preventing complications and lung damage from respiratory infections like flu, COVID-19, and pneumonia.

title: Optimize your diet for COPD relief
content:
# How eating right can help with COPD symptoms
The food you consume plays a role in fueling your body's activities. Metabolism is how your body turns food into energy. For people with COPD, breathing uses more energy, and they might feel out of breath while eating. Your body uses the food you eat as a source of energy. 

Eating whole foods with high energy content, such as protein and fat, may improve your symptoms when eating. For example, choose whole milk and full fat yogurt instead of low-fat alternatives. 

## What helps against shortness of breath when eating
* Rest before meals.
* Eat slowly and take smaller bites.
* Maintain an upright sitting position.
* Incorporate breaks between bites for deep breathing exercises.
* Front-load your meals, especially if fatigue hinders eating later in the day.
* Avoid gas-inducing foods that can make breathing difficult (eg. beans, lentils, cereal, crackers, onions and garlic).
* Consume 4 to 6 small meals daily to facilitate diaphragm movement.
* Manage liquid intake during meals to prevent feeling overly full.

## Useful nutritional guidelines to follow

* **Carbohydrates:** Opt for whole-grain bread, pasta, and fresh fruits and vegetables.
* **Fiber:** Aim for 20 to 30 grams daily from sources like bread, pasta, nuts, seeds, fruits, and vegetables.
* **Protein:** Eat a good protein source twice a day, like milk, eggs, cheese, meat, fish, poultry, nuts, or beans.
* **Fats:** Prefer mono- and polyunsaturated fats from plant sources. Limit trans fats and saturated fats found in butter, lard, fried foods, and pastries.
* **Vitamins and minerals:** Consider a multivitamin, especially if using steroids. Discuss calcium supplements with your doctor.
* **Salt:** Manage salt intake to prevent edema and high blood pressure. Explore herbs and spices for flavoring.
* **Fluids:** Stay hydrated with 6 to 8 glasses (8 ounces each) of water daily. Caffeine-free fluids and fluid-rich foods count toward your goal.
* **Medical nutritional products:** Consider liquid supplements if regular foods don't meet your nutritional needs, as recommended by your dietitian or doctor.

For a personalized meal plan, you can work with a registered dietitian nutritionist (RDN). To find a RDN ask your doctor or visit the  [Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics](https://www.eatright.org).

### Learn more
1. [Nutrition in COPD](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/living-with-copd/nutrition)

title: Risk factors for high blood pressure
content:
# Understanding High Blood Pressure Risk Factors:

Understanding risk factors helps individuals make informed lifestyle choices and engage in preventive measures to manage or reduce the risk of developing high blood pressure.

## 1. Risk Factors that you can't do much about:
**Family History**: Increased risk if parents or close relatives have high blood pressure.

**Age**: Higher risk with aging due to gradual loss of blood vessel elasticity.

**Gender**: Men under 64 more likely; after 65, women are at a higher risk.

**Race**: Black individuals more prone to high blood pressure.

**Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)**: May cause or result from high blood pressure.

## 2. Risk Factors that you have control over:
**Lack of Physical Activity**: Insufficient exercise increases the risk of high blood pressure.

**Unhealthy Diet**: High salt, calorie, saturated/trans fat, and sugar intake elevate risk.

**Overweight or Obesity**: Excess weight strains the heart and increases the risk of cardiovascular issues.

**Excessive Alcohol Consumption**: Regular heavy drinking contributes to high blood pressure.

**Sleep Apnea**: Obstructive sleep apnea raises the risk of developing high blood pressure.

**High Cholesterol**: More than half of individuals with high blood pressure also have high cholesterol.

**Diabetes**: Diabetes is often associated with high blood pressure.

**Smoking and Tobacco**: Tobacco use temporarily raises blood pressure and damages arteries.

**Stress**: Chronic stress may contribute to increased blood pressure.

## 3. Preexisting Medical Conditions:
* Pregnancy-induced hypertension
* Heart defects
* Kidney disorders

title: COPD flare-ups
content:
# COPD flare-ups

COPD flare-ups are when your symptoms suddenly get worse than usual. It's important to notice them early because getting treatment quickly can stop more damage to your lungs and keep your life from getting harder.

## Signs of a COPD flare-up
Knowing your "normal" or controlled COPD state helps to identify worsening symptoms. Flare-ups involve sudden worsening of symptoms, lasting two days or more. You may be having a flare-up if you have:

* Increased coughing
* Changes in mucus color
* Difficulty sleeping
* Worsened breathlessness
* Wheezing
* Feeling more tired

## Common COPD triggers
Anything that makes your COPD symptoms worse is called a trigger. Knowing your triggers and avoiding them may help prevent flare-ups. Some of the common triggers include:

### Smoke
Cigarette, cigar, e-cigarette, or pipe smoke, smoke from fireplaces, wood-burning stoves, campfires, or burning leaves.

### Strong smells, dust and chemicals
Scents from perfumes, cleaning products, candles, incense, hairspray, occupational exposures to dust, chemical gases, vapors, and fumes.

### Weather, pollen, and air pollution
Wind, sudden weather changes, extreme temperatures,
high humidity, pollen from weeds, trees, and grass, air pollution.

### Lung infections
Colds, flu, sinus infections, COVID-19.

### Learn more
1. [More on how to prevent flare-ups](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/living-with-copd/prevent-flare-ups)

title: Getting the most out of your COPD medication
content:
# Using your COPD medications

## Optimizing medication use
While medication doesn't cure COPD, it helps to manage symptoms and improve activity levels. Delivery methods include inhalers, nebulizers, breath-actuated devices, and pills. Here are some tips to help you adhere to your treatment:

* Establish a consistent medication schedule by setting reminders in your Huma app under "Medications".
* Utilize weekly pill boxes, routine habits, alarms, or in-home medication management programs.
* Maintain organized records, especially when traveling.

## Monitoring and adjusting medications
Regular review of your medications and inhaler technique can help you get the most out of your treatment. Staying in control of your COPD requires:

1. Communicating any ongoing symptoms, concerns, or side effects. 
2. Adjustments to your treatment plan based on your changing needs.

You can use the Huma app to help with communicating your symptoms so that your care team can pick it up.

## Types of inhalers
Your controller inhaler comes in three types:

1. **Metered dose inhalers** (MDIs): These spray the medicine.
2. **Breath actuated inhalers** (BAIs): They release the medicine when you start to breathe in.
3. **Dry powder inhalers** (DPIs): These provide the medicine as a dry powder, not a spray.

## How to improve your inhaler technique

1. Before you take your inhaler, breathe out to empty your lungs.
2. Inhale the medicine at a steady pace. Don't breathe in too fast or too slowly for your device.
3. If you're using a breath-activated inhaler, make sure you inhale with enough force to get the medicine out.
4. Breathe in through your mouth, not your nose.
5. Hold your breath for 10 seconds after taking the medicine (or as long as you can).
6. If you cough while using your inhaler, you might need to take another puff.
7. Wait for 1 minute between doses to let the medicine settle in your lungs. And if you're using a press-and-breathe inhaler, give it a shake between doses (but not all inhalers need shaking!).

Useful video on how to use a metered-dose inhaler.
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2i9_DelNqs4)

Remember, the goal is to enhance your quality of life by finding the right medication, taking it correctly, and adapting the plan as needed. 

### Learn more
1. [How to use other COPD medication devices](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/treating/copd-medications/devices)

title: What is COPD
content:
# Understanding Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
## What is COPD?
COPD is a lung condition that causes narrowing of airways, leading to difficulties in air flow and causing breathing symptoms such as shortenss of breath. Here is what you need to know: 

* COPD is a chronic condition, meaning it's there every day, and it tends to get worse over time. 
* COPD includes conditions such as chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
* In emphysema, the air sacs in your lungs are damaged, making breathing difficult.
* In bronchitis the airways of the lungs are widened allowing for too much mucus to build up, causing troublesome coughing and wheezing.

## What causes COPD?
Smoking is one of the key causes of COPD. Cigarette smoke weakens lung defenses, narrows airways, and damages lung air sacs. Other factors that can lead to COPD include: 

* Long-term exposure to chemicals, dust, and fumes at work.
* Prolonged exposure to air pollutants from sources like vehicles and factories.
* Sometimes there can be a genetic condition affecting a lung-protecting protein, causing lung damage.

## COPD risk factors
* Smoking
* Childhood lung infections
* Air pollution
* History of asthma
* Underdeveloped lungs at birth
* Age 40 and older

### Learn more
1. [https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/what-causes-copd](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/what-causes-copd)

title: Symptoms of COPD
content:
# Recognising symptoms of COPD
COPD symptoms are felt and not easily measured, so it's crucial to communicate your experiences with your healthcare provider. Sharing changes in your symptoms and how they affect you helps with making a treatment plan that is right for you. Record your symptoms on the Huma app to keep a log. 

## Common COPD symptoms
Not everyone's COPD symptoms are exactly the same but the most common symptoms include:

* Chronic cough
* Shortness of breath during everyday activities (dyspnea)
* Coughing up sputum (phlegm or mucus)
* Wheezing or chest tightness
* Fatigue or tiredness
* Difficulty taking a deep breath
* Feeling unable to breathe
* Sore throat
* Fever
* Nasal congestion

Talk to your healthcare provider if you're having any new symptoms or are experiencing worsening of your condition. 

You can help your care team better understand your daily experience of COPD by regulary recording your symptoms in the Huma app. When your symptoms worsen, they will be able to intervene early by scheduling a review or a medication change.

Managing your COPD and keeping it in check helps prevent further harm to your lungs.

title: Palliative and hospice care
content:
# Palliative and hospice care 
Many individuals with chronic conditions wait too long to begin palliative or hospice care, and that means they miss the advantages.
It might be hard to bring up, but talking about it is important to improve your quality of life.

The goals of palliative and hospice care include: 

* Improving the quality of life.
* Managing symptoms such as pain and stress.
* Providing support for both patients and their loved ones.

## Supportive care options

It's important to think about supportive care early for both patients and their loved ones. Healthcare providers can help you with any physical and emotional concerns if needed, and they make sure the care fits your needs. Supportive care is important regardless of the disease stage.

### Palliative care (at any disease stage):

* Suitable at any stage, whether it's just starting or in advanced phases.
* Starting palliative care early helps avoid unnecessary hospital visits.
* The focus is on managing symptoms while respecting your wishes and treatment goals.

### Hospice Care (advanced or end-stage disease):

* Comfort care for those in the final stage of illness, supporting both patients and caregivers.
* It's not about giving up but about making choices aligned with the patient's preferences.
* Treatment focuses on a flexible care plan for overall well-being, including ongoing medication for other medical issues.

[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4-_JPck1mrE)

### Learn more
1. [https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/treating/palliative-hospice](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/treating/palliative-hospice)

title: Importance of your lungs
content:
# Understanding your lungs
Our bodies need oxygen to stay alive, and we get it from the air we breathe. Lungs are like special bags in our chest that help us with this. The main job of your lungs is to move fresh air into your body while removing waste gases. 

Aside from this, your respiratory system has other important functions for breathing, such as:

* Adjusting air to the right temperature and humidity level.
* Protecting your body from harmful substances by coughing, sneezing, filtering, or swallowing them.
* Supporting your sense of smell.


## The parts of the respiratory system and how they work

### Airways
The airways are made up of several structures.
* Sinuses: Empty spaces in the bones near your eyes, connected to the nose, helping control air temperature and humidity.
* Nose: The main way air enters your respiratory system, with tiny hairs cleaning the air.
* Mouth: Another entrance, useful when the nose is blocked or during heavy exercise.
* Throat: Gathers air from the nose and mouth, passing it down to the windpipe.
* Windpipe (Trachea): The passage leading from the throat to the lungs.
* Bronchial Tubes: Where the windpipe splits into two main tubes. These passages bring air to the lungs.

### Lungs and blood vessels
Lungs and blood vessels team up to make sure your body gets oxygen and gets rid of waste. 

* Lungs: Your right lung has three parts called lobes, and your left lung has two lobes. Each lobe is like a balloon filled with sponge-like stuff.
* Cilia: Small hair-like structures covering airways, moving mucus to the throat for removal of dust and germs.
* Bronchioles: Smallest branches of bronchial tubes leading to air sacs (alveoli).
* Alveoli: Tiny air sacs in the lungs where oxygen and carbon dioxide exchange occurs.
* Capillaries: Very small blood vessels that help with moving the oxygen to other parts of the body.

### Muscles and bones
Your diaphragm and ribs work together to make sure you can breathe in fresh air and let out the old air.

* Diaphragm: A robust muscle wall that separates your chest from your belly. It moves down, creating suction in the chest, pulling in air to expand the lungs.
* Ribs: These bones support and shield your chest. They move a bit to assist your lungs in expanding and contracting.

Watch this short video to learn how lungs work.
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WIAoGZPw0zE)

### Learn more
1. [https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/how-lungs-work](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/how-lungs-work)

title: Diagnosing COPD
content:
# Testing for COPD
To diagnose COPD, your healthcare provider will follow a comprehensive process as outlined below.

## 1. Health history and physical exam
* Smoking history, exposure to secondhand smoke, air pollution, work-related exposures, and childhood respiratory infections.
* History of exacerbations, hospitalizations, and symptoms like shortness of breath, chronic cough, or coughing up mucus will be discussed.
* Family history of COPD or other lung diseases, the impact of symptoms on daily life, and factors triggering symptom worsening will be explored.
* Other health conditions like heart disease, osteoporosis, anxiety, or depression will be considered.

## 2. Test results
* Spirometry checks lung function and airflow problems
* Blood tests and imaging help rule out other conditions or measure COPD severity

## 3. COPD staging
Doctors use a system called 'GOLD' criteria to decide the stage or grade of your COPD. Depending on the stage, you will be offered different treatment options. 

GOLD stands for the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease. It was started in 1997 by The National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, National Institutes of Health, and the World Health Organization.

### What does the GOLD system look at?
Once a diagnosis of COPD has been made using a spirometer, your doctor will carry out an assessment of your COPD to better understand what treatment you might need. 

The assessment will focus on four fundamental areas:

1. Spirometry results
2. Severity of symptoms
3. Flare-up risk
4. Presence of other health conditions

###  Spirometry grades
Your GOLD grade depends on the spiroemetry value, FEV1. 
It is a reflection of how well you can breath. Based on the impairment of airflow, COPD is classified into four grades: 

* Grade 1: Mild
* Grade 2: Moderate
* Grade 3: Severe
* Grade 4: Very severe

Having a more advanced grade of COPD such as Grade 3 or Grade 4 makes it more likely that you will have a flare-up in the future. Another way of predicting future flare-ups is by looking at how often you had them in the past. 

### Assessing symptoms
One way of assessing and monitoring your symptoms is through a questionnaire called the COPD Assessment Test (CAT). You can do the test in the Track page of your Huma app. 

### COPD Groups 
Based on all of these criteria (spirometry results, symptom severity, flare-up risk and other health conditions), your COPD will be classified into one of these groups:

**Group A** (GOLD 1 or 2):
* Mild symptoms.
* FEV-1 is 80% or higher.
* Few or no flare-ups in the past year.
* No hospitalization for symptoms.

**Group B** (GOLD 1 or 2):
* More symptoms compared to Group A.
* FEV-1 is between 50% and 80%.
* Possibly one major flare-up but no hospitalization in the past year.

**Group C** (GOLD 3 or 4):
* Severe limitation of airflow.
* FEV-1 is between 30% and 50%.
* More than two flare-ups in the past year or at least one hospitalization.

**Group D** (GOLD 3 or 4):
* Extremely challenging breathing.
* FEV-1 is below 30%.
* At least two flare-ups in the past year or at least one hospitalization.
* Considered "end-stage" COPD with very limited lung function.

Your doctor keeps an eye on how serious your COPD is from the start of your diagnosis. They look at your stage, history, flare-up risk, and symptoms to choose the best medicines for you.

In the Huma app, we'll ask you to do things like spirometry, share your symptoms and flare-ups, answer a CAT questionnaire, and talk about your medicines. By giving us this info, we can stay on top of your COPD together and aim for a better quality of life for you.

### Learn more
1. [2023 GOLD Report](https://goldcopd.org/2023-gold-report-2/)
2. [How COPD is diagnosed](https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/copd/symptoms-diagnosis/diagnosing)

title: Improving the air in your home
content:
# How indoor air quality affects your lungs
Indoor air contains gases and particles, some too small to see. Poor indoor air quality may cause mild symptoms like headaches, lung inflammation and coughing. In severe cases it could also lead to respiratory and cardiovascular issues or even cancer. However, there are many easy ways to prevent those air pollutants from affecting your health.

Watch a short video to better understand how the air you breathe impacts your lungs.
[](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Aabz4MHXgT4)

## Improving indoor air quality
You can improve air quality indoors by identifying sources of pollution, ventilating the space and cleaning the air.

### 1. Sources of pollution 
* Avoid indoor burning: Fires, candles, and incense can release pollutants.
* Choose fragrance-free products to avoid harmful chemicals being released into the air.
* Do not smoke or vape indoors, as tobacco smoke and aerosols emit pollutants.
* Keep pets off furniture, especially if you are allergic to pets. 
* Use dust mite covering for mattresses and pillows.
* Install an EPA-certified woodstove if this is how you keep your house warm.
* Vacuum with a HEPA vacuum weekly to reduce dust and pollutants from carpets.
* Use exhaust fans in bathrooms and kitchens, especially when cooking.

### 2. Ventilation
* Open doors and windows for 15 minutes each day to let in fresh air. 
* It's not a good idea to ventilate your space on days with bad outdoor air quality.
* The quality of air is measured using an Air Quality Index (AQI), which is just a scale that is measured from 0-500. The higher the number, the bigger the risk to health. 

You can check your most recent AQI on the Track page of your Huma app. Here’s how to understand whether it is safe for you to go outdoors:

* **An AQI under 50** means good air quality. It’s safe for outdoor activities.
* As the AQI goes up, the air becomes less safe to breathe.
* **An AQI above 300** is hazardous, meaning it's very unsafe.

### 3. Air cleaning 
* Air cleaning or filtration can help to reduce pollutants already present in the air, but they cannot fully get rid of them.
* You can choose from two main types of air cleaners: portable air cleaners and HVAC (heating, ventilation, and air conditioning) systems. 

### Learn more
1. [Keeping your air indoors clean](https://www.lung.org/clean-air/indoor-air)

title: COPD and poor air quality
content:
# What is the Air Quality Index?

The Air Quality Index (AQI) measures how clean or polluted the air is. It ranges from 0 to 500 and is calculated by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency based on data about 5 main pollutants:
* Ground-level ozone,
* Particulate matter (PM2.5)
* Carbon monoxide 
* Nitrogen dioxide
* Sulfur dioxide

These numbers are put together to give us a score that tells us how safe it is to breathe the air each day.

# What counts as bad air quality?

You can check your most recent AQI on the Track page of your Huma app. Here’s how to understand whether it is safe for you to go outdoors: 

* An AQI under 50 means good air quality. It’s safe for outdoor activities.
* As the AQI goes up, the air becomes less safe to breathe.
* An AQI above 300 is hazardous, meaning it's very unsafe.

![Screenshot 2024-01-22 at 23.12.52](https://content.internal.huma.com/api/assets/education-content/40be5ee8-23f2-4629-850c-f58431a17fd0/screenshot-2024-01-22-at-23.12.52.png 'Screenshot 2024-01-22 at 23.12.52')
# How to protect yourself from poor air quality

If your AQI is below 100, it’s usually safe, but pay attention to how you feel.

On days with orange, red, purple, or maroon AQI:
* Limit your time outside to less than 30 minutes.
* Do less intense activities outdoors.
* Consider wearing an N95 or KN95 mask for better protection.
* Keep windows and doors closed.
* Use air conditioning on recirculate, or use a HEPA air cleaner.

### Learn more
1. [https://www.lung.org/blog/poor-air-quality-protection](https://www.lung.org/blog/poor-air-quality-protection)

title: Health threats from high blood pressure
content:
# Complications of High Blood Pressure:
### Heart Attack:
* **Process**: High blood pressure damages arteries, increasing the risk of blockages that can lead to a heart attack.
* **Impact**: Reduced blood flow to the heart muscle.

### Stroke:
* **Process**: High blood pressure damages blood vessels supplying the brain, leading to blockages or ruptures.
* **Impact**: Impaired blood and oxygen supply to the brain.

### Heart Failure:
* **Process**: Increased workload on the heart from high blood pressure can cause it to enlarge and fail.
* **Impact**: Inability to supply sufficient blood to the body.

### Kidney Disease or Failure:
* **Process**: High blood pressure damages arteries around the kidneys, impacting blood filtration.
* **Impact**: Reduced kidney function and potential failure.

### Vision Loss:
* **Process**: High blood pressure strains or damages blood vessels in the eyes.
* **Impact**: Impaired vision or vision loss.

### Sexual Dysfunction:
* **Effect on Men**: High blood pressure can lead to erectile dysfunction.
* **Effect on Women**: May contribute to lower libido.

### Angina:
* **Process**: Long-term high blood pressure can lead to heart disease, including microvascular disease.
* **Symptom**: Chest pain or discomfort (angina).

### Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD):
* **Process**: Atherosclerosis from high blood pressure can narrow arteries in various body parts.
* **Impact**: Pain or fatigue due to reduced blood flow in legs, arms, stomach, or head.

[More information](https://www.heart.org/en/health-topics/high-blood-pressure/health-threats-from-high-blood-pressure)

title: Symptoms of high blood pressure
content:
# What are the symptoms of high blood pressure? 
If you're seeking a list of symptoms for high blood pressure, you won't find them here because, most of the time, there are none.

High blood pressure is a ‘silent killer’ and most of the time people with high blood pressure don’t experience any symptoms. Ignoring your blood pressure due to expecting symptoms is a risky gamble with your life.

The best evidence indicates that high blood pressure does not cause headaches or nosebleeds. If your blood pressure is unusually high AND you have a headache or nosebleed and feel unwell, wait five minutes and retest. If your reading remains at 180/120 mm Hg or higher, call 911.

If you're experiencing severe headaches or nosebleeds and are otherwise unwell, contact your health care professional as they could be symptoms of other health conditions.

## Other inconclusively related symptoms:
* **Blood spots in the eyes**: More common in people with diabetes or high blood pressure. However, they are not directly related.
* **Facial flushing**: Can occur due to various triggers, but it doesn't always correlate with high blood pressure.
* **Dizziness**: While it can be a side effect of some blood pressure medications, it is sometimes associated with high blood pressure. Sudden dizziness, loss of balance, or trouble walking are warning signs of a stroke, where high blood pressure is a leading risk factor.

[Learn more](https://www.heart.org/en/health-topics/high-blood-pressure/why-high-blood-pressure-is-a-silent-killer/what-are-the-symptoms-of-high-blood-pressure)

title: Understanding blood pressure
content:
# The circulatory system and blood pressure

Your heart, blood vessels, and blood together make up the circulatory system. Every cell in your body needs oxygen to live. The circulatory system plays a key role in delivering oxygen rich blood to tissues and organs. The heart pumps blood into blood vessels called arteries, veins, and capillaries. The pressure of the blood against the wall of the blood vessels creates blood pressure. Blood pressure is expressed in units of millimetre of mercury (mmHg) which is just the way a unit of pressure is measured. 

There are two forces in a blood pressure reading: 
* Systolic pressure: when the heart pumps blood into the arteries
* Diastolic pressure: when the heart rests between beats. 

These forces are represented by numbers in a blood pressure reading. The systolic pressure is the top number and the diastolic pressure is the bottom number, for example 120/80 mmHg.

 
[Learn](https://watchlearnlive.heart.org/?moduleSelect=bpanat) more about the anatomy of blood pressure
